questions.text: Match the following theories of the origin of cholesteatoma with their descriptions: 1. Habermann's theory a) Retraction pocket theory 2. Wittmacks theory b) Basal cell hyperplasia theory 3. Sade's theory c) Epithelial invasion theory 4. Ruedi's theory d) Metaplastic theory
questions.explanation:
Theory

Description

Congenital theory
  • Presence of congenital cell remnants contributing to cholesteatoma formation.

Habermann's theory
  • Epithelial invasion theory
  • Epithelial growth from the outer ear into the middle ear through perforations contributes to cholesteatoma.

Wittmaack’s theory
  • Retraction pocket theory
  • Retraction of the tympanic membrane occurs in the attic or posterosuperior pars tensa.
  • Stratified squamous epithelium lines the outer membrane.
  • Invagination forms a retraction pocket, acting as a matrix for keratin buildup.
  • The accumulation of keratin leads to the formation of a cholesteatoma.

Sade's theory
  • Metaplastic theory
  • Metaplasia of middle ear mucosa into squamous epithelium due to repeated infections leads to cholesteatoma.

Ruedi's theory
  • Basal cell hyperplasia theory
  • Basal cell hyperplasia in the skin's germinal layer leads to keratinizing squamous epithelium formation.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is diagnosed with Congenital cholesteatoma. According to Levenson's criteria, which factor is NOT used to diagnose this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Whitish mass behind a normal tympanic membrane

options.label: B
options.text: Intact pars flaccida and pars tensa

questions.correct_answer: C. Family history of Congenital Cholesteatoma
questions.explanation:
Classification of Cholesteatoma

Congenital Cholesteatoma

Acquired Cholesteatoma
  • Congenital cholesteatoma arises from embryonic epidermal cell rests.
  • It can occur in the middle ear, petrous apex, or cerebellopontine angle.
  • In the middle ear, it presents as a white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane.
  • It causes conductive hearing loss.
  • It may be discovered during routine exams or myringotomy.
  • It can spontaneously rupture, leading to ear discharge similar to chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM).
  • Diagnosed using Levenson's criteria:
    • Presence of a whitish mass behind a normal tympanic membrane; (Option A ruled out)
    • An intact pars flaccida and pars tensa; (Option B ruled out)
    • No previous history of ear discharge or perforation;
    • No prior ear surgeries; (Option D ruled out)
    • Ruling out conditions such as canal atresia, intramembranous cholesteatoma, or giant cholesteatoma.
    • A history of otitis media was not ruled out.

Primary Acquired Cholesteatoma

Occurs without a history of prior otitis media or a preexisting perforation. Its genesis is attributed to three main theories:

(a) Invagination of pars flaccida: Persistent negative pressure causes retraction and accumulation of keratin debris, leading to an expanding cholesteatoma.

(b) Basal cell hyperplasia: Proliferation of basal cells in the pars flaccida due to infections results in cholesteatoma formation and attic perforation.

(c) Squamous metaplasia: Normal attic epithelium transforms into keratinizing squamous epithelium due to subclinical infections.

Secondary Acquired Cholesteatoma

Occurs with a preexisting perforation in the pars tensa, often a posterosuperior marginal or large central perforation. Its development is attributed to:

(a) Migration of squamous epithelium: Keratinizing squamous epithelium from the external ear or tympanic membrane migrates through the perforation into the middle ear.

(b) Metaplasia: Repeated infections cause the middle ear mucosa to transform into keratinizing squamous epithelium through the perforation.

questions.text: A patient with chronic suppurative otitis media reports that their hearing improves when the ear is discharging compared to when it is dry. Which phenomenon best explains this observation?
Which is the most common site of origin for cholesteatoma?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Chronic Draining Ear and Cholesteatoma Recidivism- PMC

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with a sensation of fullness. The child also reports occasional hearing loss. On otoscopy, a whitish mass behind the tympanic membrane is seen. Based on the information provided, which of the following is least likely to be a consequence of this patient’s diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Bone destruction due to release of enzymes

options.label: B
options.text: Bone destruction due to pressure necrosis

options.label: C
options.text: Extension into the aditus and mastoid

questions.correct_answer: B. Bone destruction due to pressure necrosis

questions.text: Which is the correct order of ossicular erosion in cholesteatoma , from most common to least common?

A 45 year out female presents with persistent ear discharge, hearing loss, and a feeling of fullness in the ear. Upon examination, the otolaryngologist performs an otoscopic examination, which reveals an abnormal growth in the ear canal. Which diagnostic test is most useful for assessing the extent of her condition and guiding surgical planning?
Which of the following statements about the treatment of cholesteatoma is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Canal Wall Down Mastoidectomy involves removing of posterior canal wallto create an open cavity.

options.label: B
options.text: Tympanoplasty for cholesteatoma repair may use synthetic prostheses to repair the ossicles.

options.label: C
options.text: William Wilde's incision is made approximately 3 cm in front of the ear.

options.label: D
options.text: Canal Wall Up Mastoidectomy involves preserving the posterior canal wall.

questions.correct_answer: C. William Wilde's incision is made approximately 3 cm in front of the ear.

questions.text: A patient with cholesteatoma is considering surgical options. Which of the following is a characteristic of a canal wall-up procedure compared to a canal wall-down procedure?

options.label: A
options.text: Requires regular cleaning of the mastoid cavity by a doctor

options.label: B
options.text: Has a lower risk of residual cholesteatoma

options.label: C
options.text: Allows for easier hearing aid fitting

options.label: D
options.text: The patients are advised not to swim due to the risk of ear infections.

questions.correct_answer: C. Allows for easier hearing aid fitting
questions.explanation:
Feature

Canal Wall Up

Canal Wall Down

Definition

It is a type of mastoidectomy in which the posterior bony canal wall is preserved. This maintains the natural anatomy of the ear canal and middle ear.

It is a surgical procedure in which the posterior and superior bony walls of the ear canal are removed. This creates an open cavity that connects the middle ear and mastoid.

Recurrence of Disease

High rate of recurrence or residual cholesteatoma

Low rate of recurrence or residual cholesteatoma (Option B ruled out)

Postoperative Care

Does not require routine cleaning

Requires regular cleaning of the mastoid cavity (once or twice a year) (Option A ruled out)

Hearing Rehabilitation

Easy to wear a hearing aid, if needed

Difficult to fit a hearing aid due to large meatus and mastoid cavity

Patient Limitations
  • No limitations to activities like swimming.
  • The patient requires a second-look surgery 6 months later to rule out residual cholesteatoma
  • The patient is advised to not participate in activities like swimming as it can lead to infection of the mastoid cavity.
  • There is no need for second-look surgery. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A patient presents with a long-standing ear infection characterised by scanty, purulent, foul-smelling discharge and a marginal perforation of the tympanic membrane. The patient also shows signs of a red and fleshy polyp. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Clinical Features

Tubotympanic CSOM

(Option A ruled out)
  • Benign or Safe CSOM.
  • Affects the antero-inferior region of the middle ear cleft (eustachian tube and mesotympanum).
  • Profuse, mucoid, odourless discharge
  • Central perforation
  • Pale polyp (if present)
  • Uncommon granulations
  • Rarely associated with cholesteatoma.
  • Rare complications
  • Mild to moderate conductive hearing loss

Atticoantral CSOM

(Option B)
  • Unsafe or Dangerous CSOM.
  • Affects the posterosuperior region of the middle ear cleft (attic, antrum, and mastoid).
  • Scanty, purulent, foul-smelling discharge
  • Attic or marginal perforation
  • Common granulations due to osteitis
  • Red and fleshy polyp (if present)
  • Frequently associated with cholesteatoma.
  • Common complications
  • Conductive or mixed hearing loss

questions.text: Which examination method is most effective for visualising a suspected cholesteatoma and assessing the condition of the ossicles in a patient with CSOM?
questions.explanation:
Examination Procedure

Purpose

Examination Under a Microscope (Otomicroscopy)
  • Provides a detailed view compared to an otoscope. (Option A ruled out)
  • Identifies discharge, cholesteatoma, ossicle condition, granulations, and signs of bone erosion.

Tuning Fork Tests and Audiogram

(Option D ruled out)
  • An audiogram identifies the type and extent of hearing loss (conductive, sensorineural, or mixed).
  • Tuning fork tests (Rinne, Weber, Schwabach) differentiate between conductive and sensorineural hearing loss.
  • Usually, CHL but SNHL may also be present in long-standing cases.

X-Ray Mastoids/High-Resolution CT Scan Temporal Bone

(Option B ruled out)
  • Determines the extent of bone destruction and mastoid pneumatization.
  • A CT scan helps identify low-lying dura or anteposed sigmoid sinus, relevant for surgical planning.

Culture and Sensitivity of Ear Discharge
  • Identifies specific bacteria causing the infection.
  • Guides appropriate antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is a Canal wall-down procedure commonly performed in the surgical treatment of Atticoantral Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM)?
Which of the following describes the characteristic features of inactive squamosal disease in CSOM?

options.label: A
options.text: Presence of cholesteatoma with mucopurulent discharge

options.label: B
options.text: Permanent perforation of the pars tensa with no active inflammation

options.label: C
options.text: The presence of retraction pockets with no active discharge

options.label: D
options.text: Healed tympanic membrane with tympanosclerosis and conductive hearing loss

questions.correct_answer: C. The presence of retraction pockets with no active discharge
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Active Mucosal Disease
  • Perforation of the pars tensa.
  • Inflammation of the middle ear mucosa.
  • Mucopurulent discharge.

Inactive Mucosal Disease (Option B ruled out)
  • Permanent perforation of the pars tensa.
  • Permanent perforation: Fusion of squamous epithelium and mucosa.
  • No active inflammation or discharge.

Healed Otitis Media

(Option D ruled out)
  • Healed but atrophic tympanic membrane
  • Prone to retraction
  • Tympanosclerosis may be present
  • Conductive hearing loss

Type

Description

Active Squamosal Disease

(Option A ruled out)
  • Presence of cholesteatoma.
  • Purulent, offensive discharge present.

Inactive Squamosal Disease
  • Presence of retraction pockets in the tympanic membrane.
  • No active discharge.
  • But keratin debris in retraction pockets can trigger infection and discharge.

questions.text: Which of the following is a typical characteristic of tubercular otitis media?

options.label: B
options.text: Multiple perforations of the tympanic membrane

options.label: C
options.text: Sudden onset of symptoms with rapid progression

questions.correct_answer: B. Multiple perforations of the tympanic membrane

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with hearing loss and a retracted tympanic membrane on otoscopic examination. The pars flaccida is completely retracted, and the retraction pocket is fully visible, and the tympanic membrane is in contact with the malleus. According to the Tos & Poulsen classification, what is the appropriate classification for this retraction?

A 30 year old patient with chronic otitis media presents with a perforated tympanic membrane and erosion of the malleus. The surgeon plans to repair the tympanic membrane and place a graft on the remaining malleus. According to Wullstein's classification, which type of tympanoplasty is being performed?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Type I

Myringoplasty: Repair of a perforated tympanic membrane using a graft over the malleus.

Type II

Graft placed on the incus and perforated tympanic membrane.

Type III

Graft placed directly on the stapes head in absence of the malleus and incus (myringostapediopexy or columella tympanoplasty).

Type IV

Graft placed over the footplate of the stapes in the absence of the Malleus, Incus and Stapes suprastructure (cavum minor), allowing sound to act directly on the footplate.

Type V

Fenestration operation: Creation of a new window on the lateral semicircular canal, creating an alternate pathway for the sound to travel instead of the natural pathway.
Type VI Sonoinversion: Graft placed over the round window, reversing the pathway of sound transmission (Sound now travels from Oval window to Round window)
